rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 4:21
rsbNotes.text: 4:21 laid him on the bed of the man of God. She refuses to accept the death of her son and conceals his body in Elisha’s room so that the ritual of mourning will not begin (Gen. 50:10; 2 Chr. 35:25; Job 2:12, 13; Dan. 10:2; Mark 5:38; John 11:33).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 4:23
rsbNotes.text: 4:23 It is neither new moon nor Sabbath. Ancient Israel had a lunar calendar, and a festival was celebrated at each New Moon (Num. 10:10; 28:11–15; Ezra 3:5; Neh. 10:33; Is. 1:13, 14; Amos 8:5). The law did not permit work on the Sabbath, and possibly not on the New Moon either (Ex. 16:23; 20:8–10; 1 Sam. 20:5; 1 Chr. 23:31).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 4:27
rsbNotes.text: 4:27 caught hold of his feet. Doing this was a sign of respect (John 11:32).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 4:38
rsbNotes.text: 4:38 Set on the large pot. During a famine, Elisha’s request was not trivial (cf. 1 Kin. 17:11–13).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 4:39
rsbNotes.text: 4:39 wild gourds. There exist in this area several more or less poisonous gourds that resemble edible plants.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 4:42
rsbNotes.text:
4:42 Baal-shalishah. In the hill country of Ephraim, on the Brook of Kanah.

bread of the firstfruits. By bringing the firstfruits of the harvest, the man showed his dedication to Elijah and his gratitude for his prophetic work (Lev. 2:14; 23:9–21; Deut. 18:3–5).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:1
rsbNotes.text: 5:1 the king of Syria. This king and the king of Israel (v. 5) are probably Ben-hadad II (8:7; 13:3; 1 Kin. 20:1) and Jehoram (1:17; 3:1; 9:24).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:2
rsbNotes.text: 5:2 raids. During the long history of tension between Israel and Syria there were often skirmishes and raids along the border.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:5
rsbNotes.text:
5:5 a letter to the king of Israel. The Syrian king sends an official letter to the king of Israel introducing Naaman and asking for a favor on his behalf. The Syrian king has mistakenly supposed that Elisha’s work is at the command of the Israelite king.

ten talents of silver, six thousand shekels of gold. That is, about 750 pounds of silver and 150 pounds of gold.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:7
rsbNotes.text: 5:7 he tore his clothes. This was a sign of great distress (1 Kin. 21:27 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:8
rsbNotes.text:
5:8 Why have you torn your clothes. Elisha scolds the king for reacting to the Syrian request with such alarm and not believing that God could help him.

he may know that there is a prophet in Israel. See 3:11; 8:7, 8; 1 Kin. 17:24; 18:36. Elisha responds affirmatively to the Syrian gesture (v. 3).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:10
rsbNotes.text: 5:10 Elisha sent a messenger. Both Elijah and Elisha would often test the faith of the people to whom they ministered (1 Kin. 17:13; 2 Kin. 4:3, 4). In this case, Elisha does not even meet with Naaman but sends instructions through a messenger instead.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:11
rsbNotes.text: 5:11 wave his hand over the place. Not realizing the importance of divine freedom and the critical role of faith, Naaman thought there was something contemptible about having to bathe seven times in the river.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:12
rsbNotes.text: 5:12 Abana and Pharpar, the rivers of Damascus. If the prophetic healing was a meaningless ritual, Naaman might as well have stayed at home.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:15
rsbNotes.text: 5:15 there is no God in all the earth but in Israel. Naaman was not merely saying that the Lord was more powerful than the Syrian gods; he was confessing that there is only one God, the Lord. In saying this, Naaman adopts the faith of Israel as his own (1 Kin. 18:39).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:16
rsbNotes.text: 5:16 As the Lord lives. The words are an oath (1 Kin. 1:17 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:17
rsbNotes.text: 5:17 two mules’ load of earth. People in the ancient Near East believed that the gods were tied to the lands they ruled. Naaman asks for dirt from the Lord’s land to sanctify the altar he plans to build for Him in another country.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:18
rsbNotes.text: 5:18 Rimmon. The word “Rimmon” (lit. “pomegranate”) is a parody of the name Ramanu, the Syrian storm god corresponding to Baal. This chief deity of Syria was also known by the name Hadad (Zech. 12:11).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:22
rsbNotes.text: 5:22 sons of the prophets. See note 1 Kin. 20:35.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:26
rsbNotes.text: 5:26 money. The word refers not to coins (which were probably not yet in use), but to quantities of gold or silver.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 5:27
rsbNotes.text: 5:27 to you and to your descendants. Sin is not only individual, but corporate (Ex. 20:5).
